results.title: Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: Working Title Films, Alison Owen, Eric Fellner, Tim Bevan and Shekhar Kapur
results.brief_description: Elizabeth begins during the tense period before Elizabeth I became Queen of England. She is a young vivacious girl thrust suddenly into the machiavellian world of politics when she is tried for treason at the age of 21. Surviving this she becomes Queen, and the film charts the beginning of her reign as she struggles to learn the skills of a monarch. Cate Blanchett is amazing as a young woman who slowly casts off her youth and becomes the legendary Virgin Queen that ruled the Elizabethan age. Shekhar Kapur’s film manages to be both entertaining and historically insightful. Lavish costumes and an excellent cast make this compelling viewing. The cast also includes Joseph Fiennes as Elizabeth’s lover Lord Robert Dudley, Richard Attenborough as Sir William Cecil, and Geoffrey Rush as her political adviser Sir Francis Walsingham. (Awards: Cate Blanchett won the 1998 Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Drama, and “Elizabeth” won the 1998 Academy Award for Best Makeup)

results.title: Eliza Fraser
results.brief_description: A 19th Century seafarer and his wife journey to Australia, where the crew mutinies, and they are captured by Aborigines. The seafarer is killed and his wife has many adventures before returning home. Stars Susannah York, Trevor Howard, Noel Ferrier and John Waters.

results.title: Elie Wiesel: first person singular [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Lives and Legacies Films, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Robert H Gardner
results.brief_description: Elie Wiesel is a Nobel Prize-winning author, Holocaust survivor, and human rights activist. Born in the provincial town of Sighet, Romania on September 30, 1928, Wiesel was just fifteen when he, his family and most of the Sighet population were deported to Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland. Of Wiesel’s entire family, only he and his two older sisters survived. In this documentary, made for television, Wiesel is interviewed extensively and discusses his life, experiences of World War II, faith, Jewish background, relationship with his family, in particular his father, and his writings. Actor William Hurt narrates passages from Wiesel’s book ‘Night’, a memoir based on his time spent in Auschwitz as a teenager, decrying the horrors he witnessed first hand. Wiesel also offers observations on such current events as the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks and the Israeli-Palestine war. This documentary utilises black and white photographs of Europe, before and during World War II, and Wiesel’s own photos depicting the stages of his life. With background music by Bach, and a melancholy original score by Leonard Lionnet, this is a thought-provoking and intelligent work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lives and Legacies Films, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Robert H Gardner

results.title: Eli, Eli, Lamma Sabachtani?
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Francois Seguillon and Andre-Marcel Gagnon
results.brief_description: The cry from the Cross echoed in a film parable, told without words, where sculptured figures of the anguished Christ mix with contemporary scenes of city life. Musical accompaniment is a Dies Irae in memory of the victims of Auschwitz. Religious processions suggest man’s spiritual insight; scenes in city parks or streets reflect the bland tolerance of human suffering.

results.title: Elgar: Portrait of a Composer
results.creator_credit: BBC, Humphrey Burton and Ken Russell
results.brief_description: The moving story of 19th Century English composer, Edward Elgar, told through Huw Wheldon’s commentary and Elgar’s own music. Against sweeping panoramas of the Malvern Hills, a major inspiration for Elgar, it blends archival footage with the stunning visual imagery characteristic of Ken Russell’s work.

results.title: Elgar Cello Concerto
results.brief_description: Julian Lloyd Webber performs the Elgar Cello Concerto in E Minor Op. 85 and Romance Op. 62 on his Bartanksy Stradivarius (1684) cello. He is accompanied by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Sir Yehudi Menuhin. The video includes a short introduction by Robert Walker.

results.title: Elevator Operator – Courtney Barnett
results.brief_description: Courtney Barnett’s ‘Elevator Operator’ (2016) leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

constellations_primary.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_primary.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.description: The music video as a mini movie is an enduring concept within the genre, first achieving mainstream popularity with Michael Jackson’s Thriller (1983). This idea was toyed with in Courtney Barnett’s Elevator Operator(2016), which leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

results.title: Elevation
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission and Stephen Cummins
results.brief_description: This queer short film begins with two men in bed next to each other. The focus then shifts to the two men encountering each other in an elevator. As they shift in bed, or begin to make love in the lift, the film becomes a celebration of the body and movement: the erotics are a series of dances choreographed to an experimental music score. This is one of a number of short films directed by Stephen Cummins which integrate modern dance with film.

results.title: Elephants: their last stand
results.brief_description: This film is about the conflict between people and elephants. In the Samburu district of Kenya, herds of elephants have raided farms, trampled crops and imperilled a struggling people’s way of life. Unfortunately there is no easy solution to the problem of whether to eliminate the elephants or to protect them as part of the country’s unique heritage.
